tags.soleSupplier.places.2: Lazy town square where everyone lives on resource payments
tags.tabooTreasure.description: The natives here produce something that is both fabulously valuable and strictly forbidden elsewhere in the sector. It may be a lethally addictive drug, forbidden gengineering tech, vat-grown "perfect slaves", or a useful substance that can only be made through excruciating human suffering. This treasure is freely traded on the world, but bringing it elsewhere is usually an invitation to a long prison stay or worse.
tags.tabooTreasure.enemies.3: Local warlord who controls the treasure
tags.tabooTreasure.friends.0: Reformer seeking to end its use
tags.tabooTreasure.friends.1: Innovator trying to repurpose the treasure in innocent ways
tags.tabooTreasure.friends.2: Wretched addict unwillingly prey to the treasure
tags.tabooTreasure.complications.0: The treasure is extremely hard to smuggle
tags.tabooTreasure.complications.1: Its use visibly marks a user
tags.tabooTreasure.complications.2: The natives consider it for their personal use only
tags.tabooTreasure.things.1: Smuggling tech that could hide the good perfectly
tags.tabooTreasure.things.2: Blackmail data on offworld buyers of the good
tags.tabooTreasure.places.0: Den where the good is used
tags.tabooTreasure.places.1: Market selling the good to locals and a few outsiders
tags.tabooTreasure.places.2: Factory or processing area where the good is created
tags.terraformFailure.description: This world was marginal for human habitation when it was discovered, but the Mandate or the early government put in pretech terraforming engines to correct its more extreme qualities. The terraforming did not entirely work, either failing of its own or suffering the destruction of the engines during the Silence. The natives are only partly adapted to the world's current state, and struggle with the environment.
tags.terraformFailure.enemies.0: Brutal ruler who cares only for their people
tags.terraformFailure.enemies.1: Offworlder trying to loot the damaged engines
tags.terraformFailure.enemies.2: Warlord trying to seize limited habitable land
tags.terraformFailure.friends.0: Local trying to fix the engines
tags.terraformFailure.complications.0: The engines produced too much of something instead of too little
tags.terraformFailure.complications.1: The engines were hijacked by aliens with different preferences
tags.terraformFailure.complications.2: It was discovered that an earth-like environment would eventually cause a catastrophic disaster
tags.terraformFailure.things.0: Parts to repair or restore the engines
tags.terraformFailure.things.2: Valuable local tech devised to cope with the world
tags.terraformFailure.places.0: Zone of tolerable gravity or temperature
tags.terraformFailure.places.1: Native settlement built to cope with the environment
tags.theocracy.description: The planet is ruled by the priesthood of the predominant religion or ideology. The rest of the locals may or may not be terribly pious, but the clergy have the necessary military strength, popular support or control of resources to maintain their rule. Alternative faiths or incompatible ideologies are likely to be both illegal and socially unacceptable.
tags.theocracy.complications.1: The theocracy is decadent and hated by the common folk
tags.theocracy.complications.2: The theocracy is divided into mutually hostile sects
tags.theocracy.complications.3: The theocracy is led by aliens
tags.tombWorld.description: Tomb worlds are planets that were once inhabited by humans before the Silence. The sudden collapse of the jump gate network and the inability to bring in the massive food supplies required by the planet resulted in starvation, warfare, and death. Most tomb worlds are naturally hostile to human habitation and could not raise sufficient crops to maintain life. The few hydroponic facilities were usually destroyed in the fighting, and all that is left now are ruins, bones, and silence.
tags.tombWorld.complications.0: The ruins are full of booby-traps left by the final inhabitants
tags.tombWorld.complications.1: The world's atmosphere quickly degrades anything in an opened building
tags.tombWorld.complications.2: A handful of desperate natives survived the silence
tags.tombWorld.complications.3: The structures are unstable and collapsing
tags.tradeHub.description: This world is a major crossroads for local interstellar trade. It is well-positioned at the nexus of several short-drill trade routes, and has facilities for easy transfer of valuable cargoes and the fueling and repairing of starships. The natives are accustomed to outsiders, and a polyglot mass of people from every nearby world can be found trading here.
tags.tradeHub.friends.2: Merchant prince in need of catspaws
tags.tradeHub.complications.0: An outworlder faction schemes to seize the trade hub
tags.tradeHub.complications.1: Saboteurs seek to blow up a rival's warehouses
tags.tradeHub.complications.2: Enemies are blockading the trade routes
tags.tradeHub.complications.3: Pirates lace the hub with spies
tags.tradeHub.things.3: Box of legitimate tax stamps indicating customs dues have been paid
tags.tyranny.description: The local government is brutal and indifferent to the will of the people. Laws may or may not exist, but the only one that matters is the whim of the rulers on any given day. Their minions swagger through the streets while the common folk live in terror of their appetites. The only people who stay wealthy are friends and servants of the ruling class.
tags.tyranny.friends.3: The tyrant rules with vastly superior technology
tags.tyranny.complications.0: The tyrant is a figurehead for a cabal of powerful men and women
tags.tyranny.complications.1: The people are resigned to their suffering
tags.tyranny.complications.2: The tyrant is hostile to meddlesome outworlders
tags.unbrakedAi.description: Artificial intelligences are costly and difficult to create, requiring a careful sequence of growth stages in order to bring them to sentience before artificial limits on cognition speed and learning development are installed. These brakes prevent runaway cognition metastasis. This world has an unbraked AI on it, probably with a witting or unwitting corps of servants. Unbraked AIs are quite insane, but they learn and reason with a speed impossible for humans, and can demonstrate a truly distressing subtlety.
tags.unbrakedAi.enemies.2: Government official dependent on the AI
tags.unbrakedAi.complications.0: The AI's presence is unknown to the locals
tags.unbrakedAi.complications.1: The locals depend on the AI for some vital service
tags.unbrakedAi.complications.2: The AI appears to be harmless
tags.unbrakedAi.complications.3: The AI has fixated on the group's ship's computer
tags.unbrakedAi.things.2: Perfectly tabulated blackmail on government officials
tags.urbanizedSurface.description: The world's land area is covered with buildings that extend downward for multiple levels. Such worlds either have a population in the trillions, extremely little land area, or are largely-abandoned due to some past catastrophe. Agriculture and resource extraction are part of the urban complex, and there may be an advanced maintenance system that may not be entirely under the control of present natives.
tags.urbanizedSurface.enemies.2: Deep-dwelling prophet who considers "the sky" a blasphemy to be quelled
tags.urbanizedSurface.friends.2: Harried engineer trying to maintain ancient works
tags.urbanizedSurface.complications.0: The urban blocks are needed to survive the environment
tags.urbanizedSurface.complications.1: The blocks were part of an ancient device of world-spanning size
tags.urbanizedSurface.complications.2: The blocks require constant maintenance to avoid dangerous types of decay
tags.urbanizedSurface.things.1: Map of the secret ways of a zone
tags.urbanizedSurface.things.2: Passkey into restricted hab block areas
tags.urbanizedSurface.places.0: Giant hab block now devoid of inhabitants
tags.urbanizedSurface.places.2: Seawater mine full of salt and massive flowing channels
tags.utopia.description: Natural and social conditions on this world have made it a paradise for its inhabitants, a genuine utopia of happiness and fulfillment. This is normally the result of drastic human engineering, including brain-gelding, neurochemical control, personality curbs, or complete "humanity" redefinitions. Even so, the natives are extremely happy with their lot, and may wish to extend that joy to poor, sad outsiders.
tags.utopia.enemies.2: Brutal tyrant who rules through inexorable happiness
tags.utopia.friends.1: Bloody-handed guerilla leader of a rebellion of madmen
tags.utopia.friends.2: Outsider trying to find a way to reverse the utopian changes
tags.utopia.complications.0: The natives really are deeply and contentedly happy with their altered lot
tags.utopia.complications.1: The utopia produces something that attracts others
tags.utopia.complications.2: The utopia works on converting outsiders through persuasion and generosity
tags.utopia.complications.3: The utopia involves some sacrifice that's horrifying to non-members
tags.utopia.things.0: Portable device that applies the utopian change
tags.utopia.things.1: Plans for a device that would destroy the utopia
tags.utopia.things.2: Goods created joyfully by the locals
tags.warlords.description: The world is plagued by warlords. Numerous powerful men and women control private armies sufficiently strong to cow whatever local government may exist. On the lands they claim, their word is law. Most spend their time oppressing their own subjects and murderously pillaging those of their neighbors. Most like to wrap themselves in the mantle of ideology, religious fervor, or an ostensibly legitimate right to rule.
tags.warlords.complications.0: The warlords are willing to cooperate to fight mutual threats
tags.warlords.complications.1: The warlords favor specific religions or races over others
tags.warlords.complications.2: The warlords are using substantially more sophisticated tech than others
tags.warlords.complications.3: Some of the warlords are better rulers than the government
tags.xenophiles.description: The natives of this world are fast friends with a particular alien race. The aliens may have saved the planet at some point in the past, or awed the locals with superior tech or impressive cultural qualities. The aliens might even be the ruling class on the planet.
tags.xenophiles.complications.0: The enthusiasm is due to alien psionics or tech
tags.xenophiles.complications.1: The enthusiasm is based on a lie, the aliens strongly dislike their groupies
tags.xenophiles.complications.2: The aliens feel obliged to rule humanity for its own good
tags.xenophiles.things.2: Sophisticated xenolinguistic and xenocultural research data
tags.xenophobes.description: The natives are intensely averse to dealings with outworlders. Whether through cultural revulsion, fear of tech contamination, or a genuine immunodeficiency, the locals shun foreigners from offworld and refuse to have anything to do with them beyond the bare necessities of contact. Trade may or may not exist on this world, but if it does, it is almost certainly conducted by a caste of untouchables and outcasts.
tags.xenophobes.enemies.1: Native convinced some wrong was done to him
tags.xenophobes.complications.0: The natives are symptomless carriers of a contagious and dangerous disease
tags.xenophobes.complications.1: The natives are exceptionally vulnerable to offworld diseases
tags.xenophobes.complications.2: The natives require elaborate purification rituals after speaking to an offworlder or touching them
tags.xenophobes.complications.3: The local ruler has forbidden any mercantile dealings with outworlders
tags.xenophobes.places.1: Public ritual not open to outsiders
tags.zombies.description: This menace may not take the form of shambling corpses, but some disease, alien artifact, or crazed local practice produces men and women with habits similar to those of murderous cannibal undead. These outbreaks may be regular elements in local society, either provoked by some malevolent creators or the consequence of some local condition.
tags.zombies.complications.2: The process is voluntary among devotees
tags.zombies.things.2: Details of the cult's conversion process
tags.zombies.places.2: Fortified bunker that was overrun from within
faction.goal.military.description: Destroy a number of Force assets of rival factions equal to your faction's Force rating. Difficulty is 1/2 number of assets destroyed.
faction.goal.commercial.description: Destory a number of Wealth assets of rival factions equal to your faction's Wealth rating. Difficulty is 1/2 number of assets destroyed.
faction.goal.coup.description: Destroy a number of Cunning assets of rival factions equal to your faction's Cunning rating. Difficulty is 1/2 number of assets destroyed.
faction.goal.seizure.description: Take control of a planet, becoming the legitimate planetary government. Difficulty equal to half the average of the current ruling faction's Force, Cunning, and Wealth ratings. If the planet somehow lacks any opposing faction to resist the seizure, it counts as Difficulty 1.
faction.goal.influence.description: Plant a Base of Influence on a new planet. Difficulty 1, +1 if the attempt is contested by a rival faction.
faction.goal.blood.description: Inflict a number of hit points of damage on enemy faction assets or bases equal to your faction's total Force, Cunning, and Wealth ratings. Difficulty 2.
faction.goal.peaceable.description: Don't take an Attack action for four turns. Difficulty 1.
faction.goal.destroy.description: Destroy a rival faction. Difficulty equal to 1 plus the average of the faction's Force, Cunning, and Wealth ratings.
faction.goal.inside.description: Have a number of stealthed assets on worlds with other planetary governments equal to your Cunning score. Units that are already stealthed on worlds when this goal is adopted don't count. Difficulty 2.
faction.goal.valor.description: Destroy a Force asset with a minimum purchase rating higher than your faction's Force rating. Thus, if your Force is 3, you need to destroy a unit that requires Force 4 or higher to purchase. Difficulty 2.
faction.goal.wealth.description: Spend FacCreds equal to four times your faction's Wealth rating on bribes and influence. This money is effectively lost, but the goal is then considered accomplished. The faction's Wealth rating must increase before this goal can be selected again. Difficulty 2.
faction.assets.baseOfInfluence.descripti: This asset is special, and is required for purchasing or upgrading units on a particular world. Any damage done to a Base of Influence is also done to a faction's hit points. The cost of a Base of Influence equals its maximum hit points, which can be any number up to the total maximum hit points of its owning faction. A faction's bases of influence don't count against their maximum assets. A Base of Influence can only be purchased with the Expand Influence action.
faction.assets.blackmail.description: Selectively degrade the effectiveness of an asset. Any attempt to attack or defend against Blackmail loses any bonus dice earned by tags.
faction.assets.boltholes.description: Equipped with a number of postech innovations to make cleaning them out a costly and dangerous pursuit. If a faction Special Forces of Military Unit asset on the same plant as the Boltholes suffers damage sufficient to destroy it, it is instead set at 0 HP and rendered untouchable and unusable until it is repaired to full strength. If the Boltholes are destroyed before this happens, the asset is destroyed with them.
faction.assets.bookOfSecrets.description: Exhaustively cataloged psychometric records on important and influential local figures, allowing uncanny accuracy in predicting their actions. Once per turn, a Book of Secrets allows the faction to reroll one die for an action taken on that world or force an enemy faction to reroll one die. This reroll can only be forced once per turn, no matter how many Books of Secrets are owned.
faction.assets.covertShipping.descriptio: Quiet interstellar asset transport. Any one Special Forces unit can be moved between any worlds within three hexes of the Covert Shipping at the cost of one FacCred.
faction.assets.covertTransitNet.descript: Facilities web an area of space with a network of smugglers and gray-market freighter captains. As an action, any Special Forces assets can be moved between any worlds within three hexes of the Covert Transit Net.
faction.assets.crackedComms.description: A cryptographic asset for the interception and deciphering of enemy communications. Friendly fire can be induced with the right interference. If the Cracked Comms succeeds in defending against an attack, it can immediately cause the attacking asset to make an attack against itself for normal damage or counterattack results.
faction.assets.cyberninjas.description: Outfitted with the latest in personal stealth cyberware, cybern injas are designed to avoid all but the most careful scans.
faction.assets.demagogues.description: Popular leaders of a particular faith or ideology that can be relied upon to point their followers in the direction of maximum utility.
faction.assets.falseFront.description: This asset allows a faction to preserve more valuable resources. If another asset on the planet suffers enough damage to destroy it, the faction can sacrifice the false front instead to nullify the killing blow.
faction.assets.informers.description: Minions that lace a planet's underworld, watchful for intruders. They can choose to Attack a faction without specifying a target asset. On a successful Cunning v. Cunning attack, all Stealthed assets on the planet belonging to that faction are revealed. Informers can target a faction even if none of their assets are visible on a world; at worst, they simply learn that there are no stealthed assets.
faction.assets.lobbyists.description: Usable to block the governmental permission that is sometimes required to buy an asset or transport it into a system. When a rival faction gains permission to do so, the Lobbyists can make an immediate Cunning vs. Cunning test against the faction; if successful, the permission is withdrawn and cannot be re-attempted until next turn.
faction.assets.organizationMoles.descrip: These can subvert and confuse enemy assets, striking to damage their cohesion.
faction.assets.panopticonMatrix.descript: These facilities weave braked-AI intelligence analysts into a web of observation capable of detecting the slightest evidence of intruders on a world. Every rival Stealthed asset on the planet must succeed in a Cunning vs Cunning test at the beginning of every turn or lose their Stealth. The owner also gains an additional die on all Cunning attacks and defenses on that planet.
faction.assets.partyMachines.description: Political blocks control particular cities or regions... blocks that are firmly in control of the faction. Each turn, a Party Machine provides 1 FacCred to its owning faction.
faction.assets.popularMovements.descript: A planet-wide surge of enthusiasm for a cause controlled by the faction. This support pervades all levels of government, and the government always grants any asset purchase or mevement requests made by the faction.
faction.assets.saboteurs.description: Minions rained in launching strikes against enemy operations. An asset attacked by saboteurs cannot apply any Use Asset Ability action until the start of the attacking faction's next turn. This applies whether or not the attack was successful.
faction.assets.seditionists.description: These assets sap a target's loyalty and will to obey.For a cost of 1d4 FacCreds, the Seditionists can attach themselves to an enemy asset. Until they attach to a different asset or no longer share the same planet, the affected asset cannot attack. If the asset is destroyed, the Seditionists survive.
faction.assets.seductresses.description: They and their male equivalents subvert the leadership of enemy assets. As an action, a Seductress can travel to any world within one hex. As an attack, a Seductress does no damage, but an asset that has been successfully attacked immediately reveals any other Stealthed assets of that faction on the planet. Only Special Forces units can attack a Seductress.
faction.assets.smugglers.description: Men and women skilled in extracting personnel. For one FacCred, the smugglers asset can transport itself and/or any one Special Forces unit to a planet up to two hexes away.
faction.assets.stealth.description: Not an asset, per se, but a special quality that can be purchased for a another Special Forces asset on the planet. An asset that has been Stealthed cannot be detected or attacked by other factions. If the unit normally requires the permission of a planetary government to be moved onto a planet, that permission may be foregone. An asset loses its Stealth if it is used to attack or defend.
faction.assets.transportLockdown.descrip: These techniques involve selective pressure on local routing and shipping companies. On a successful Cunning vs. Cunning attack against a rival faction, the rival faction cannot transport assets onto that planet without spending 1d4 FacCreds and waiting one turn.
faction.assets.treachery.description: Traitors can attack an enemy asset. On a successful attack, the Treachery asset is lost, 5 FacCreds are gained, and the targeted asset switches sides to join the traitor's faction, even if the faction does not otherwise have the attributes necessary.
faction.assets.tripwireCells.description: These observers are alert to the arrival of stealthed units. Whenever a stealthed asset lands or is purchased on a planet with tripwire cells, the Cells make an immediate Cunning vs Cunning attack against the owning faction. If successful, the asset loses its stealth.
faction.assets.vanguardCadres.descriptio: Followers of the movement are inspired sufficiently to take up arms and fight on behalf of their leadership.
faction.assets.beachheadLanders.descript: A collection of short-range, high-capacity spike drive ships capable of moving large numbers of troops. As an action, the asset may move any number of assets on the planet, including itself, to any world within one hex at a cost of one FacCred per asset moved.
faction.assets.blockadeFleets.descriptio: A ragtag lot of corsairs, pirates, privateers, and other deniable assets. When they successfully Attack an enemy faction asset, they steal 1d4 FacCreds from the target faction as well. This theft can occur to a faction only once per turn, no matter how many blockade fleets attack. As an action, this asset may also move itself to a world within one hex.
faction.assets.capitalFleets.description: The pride of an empire, this is a collection of massive capital warships without peer in most sectors. Capital fleets are expensive to keep flying, and cost an additional 2 FacCreds of maintenance each turn. As an action, they may move to any world within three hexes of their current location. Planetary government permission is required to raise a capital fleet, but not to move one into a system.
faction.assets.counterintelUnits.descrip: These security units specialize in code breaking, internal security, and monitoring duties. They can crack open enemy plots long before they have time to come to fruition.
faction.assets.cunningTraps.description: This asset covers all the myriad strategems of war, from induced landslides to spreading local diseases.
faction.assets.deepStrikeLanders.descrip: These advanced transport ships are capable of moving an asset long distances. As an action, any one non-Starship asset, including itself, can be moved between two worlds within three hexes of the deep strike landers, at a cost of 2 FacCreds. This movement can be done even if the local planetary government objects, albeit doing so is usually an act of open war.
faction.assets.eliteSkirmishers.descript: These lightly-equipped troops are trained for guerrilla warfare and quick raids.
faction.assets.extendedTheater.descripti: These facilities allow for transporting assets long distances. As an action, any one non-Starship asset, including itself, can be moved between any two worlds within two hexes of the extended theater, at a cost of 1 FacCred.
faction.assets.gravtankFormations.descri: These tank formations are composed of advaned postech gravtank units that are capable of covering almost any terrain and cracking even the toughest defnesive positions.
faction.assets.guerrillaPopulace.descrip: Such assets reflect popular support among the locals and a cadre of men and women willing to fight as partisans.
faction.assets.hardenedPersonnel.descrip: These are the employees and support staff of the faction that have been trained in defensive fighting and equipped with suply caches and hardened fallback positions.
faction.assets.heavyDropAssets.descripti: These craft allow for the transport of resources from one world to another. As an action, any one non-Starship asset, including this one, may be moved to any world within one hex for one FacCred.
faction.assets.hitmen.description: Crudely-equipped thugs and assassins with minimal training that have been aimed at a rival faction's leadership.
faction.assets.integralProtocols.descrip: A complex web of braked-AI supported sensors and redundant security checks used to defat attempts to infiltrate an area they can defend only against attacks versus cunning, but they add an additional die to the defender's roll.
faction.assets.militiaUnits.description: Groups of lightly-equipped irregular troops with rudimentary military traning but no heavy support.
faction.assets.planetaryDefenses.descrip: Massive mag cannons and gravititic braker gun arrays designed to defend against starship bombardments and repel unauthorized landing. Planetary defenses can only defned against attacks by Starship-type assets.
faction.assets.postechInfantry.descripti: The backbone of most planetary armies, these well-trained soldiers are usually equipped with mag weaponry and combat field uniforms, and have heavy support units attached.
faction.assets.pretechInfantry.descripti: The cream of the stellar ground forces, elite troups kitted out in the best pretech weaponry and armor available, with sophisticated heavy support weaponry integral to the unit.
faction.assets.pretechLogistics.descript: These assets represent caches, smugglers, or internal research and salvage programs. As an action a pretech logistics asset allow the owner to buy one Force asset on that world that requires up to tech level 5 to purchase. This asset costs half again as many FacCreds as usual, rounded up. Only one asset can be purchased per turn.
faction.assets.psychicAssassins.descript: Combat-trained psychics equipped with advanced pretech stealth gear and psitech weaponry. Psychic assassins automatically start Stealthed when purchased.
faction.assets.securityPersonnel.descrip: Standard civilian guards or policemen, usually equipped with nonlethal weaponry or personal sidearms.
faction.assets.spaceMarines.description: Heavily-armored specialist troops trained for ship boarding actions and opposed landings. As an action they can move to any world within one hex of their current location, wheather or not the planetary government permits it.
faction.assets.strikeFleets.description: Forces composed of frigate to cruiser-class vessels equipped with space-to-ground weaponry and sophisticated defenses against light planetary weaponry. As an action, they can move to any world within one hex of their current location.
faction.assets.zealots.description: Members of the faction so utterly dedicated that they are willing to launch suicide attacks or hold positions to the death. Zealots take 1d4 damage every time they launch a successful attack or perform a counterattack.
faction.assets.bankAssets.description: Once per turn, the faction can ignore one cost or FacCred loss imposed by another faction. This does not require an action. Multiple bank assets allow multiple losses to be ignored.
faction.assets.blockadeRunners.descripti: These starship captains excel at transporting goods through unfriendly lines. As an action, a blockade runner can transfer itself or any one Military Unit or Special Forces to a world within three ehxes for a cost of two FacCreds. They can even move units that would otherwise required planetary government permission to enter.
faction.assets.commoditiesBrokers.descri: They substantially lessen the cost of large-scale investments by timing materials purchases properly. As an action, the owner of a commodities broker can roll 1d8; that many FacCreds are subtracted from the cost of their next asset purchase, down to a minimum of half normal price, rounded down.
faction.assets.franchise.description: This asset reflects a deniable connection with a local licensee for the faction's goods and services. When a Franchise successfully attacks an enemy asset, the enemy faction loses one FacCred (if available), which is gained by the Franchise's owner. This loss can happen only once a turn, no matter how many Franchises attack.
faction.assets.freighterContract.descrip: A special link with heavy shipping spacers. As an action, the faction may move any one non-Force asset, including this one, to any world within two hexes at a cost of one FacCred.
faction.assets.harvesters.description: These gather the natural resources of a world, whether ore, biologicals, or other unprocessed goods. As an action, the Harvesters' owning faction may roll 1d6. On 3+, gain one FacCred.
faction.assets.hostileTakeover.descripti: This asset can seize control of damaged and poorly-controlled assets. If a Hostile Takeover does enough damage to destroy an asset, the target is instead reduced to 1 hit point and acquired by the Hostile Takeover's owning faction.
faction.assets.laboratory.description: The lab allows a world to make hesitant progress in tech. The presence of a Laboratory allows assets to be purchased on that world as if it had Tech Level 4.
faction.assets.lawyers.description: Sophists in immaculate suits or charismatic tribal skalds, lawyers hav ethe ability to tie an enemy up in the coils of their own internal rues, damaging assets with confusion and red tape. Lawyers cannot attack or counterattack Force assets.
faction.assets.localInvestments.descript: These give the faction substantial influence over the commerce on a world. Any other faction that tries to buy an asset on that planet must pay one extra FacCred. This money is not given to the investments' owner, but is lost. This penalty is only applied once.
faction.assets.marketers.description: Deployed to confuse enemy factions into untimely investments. As an action, the marketers may test Cunning vs. Wealth against a rival faction's asset. If successful, the target faction must immediately pay half the asset's purchase cost, rounded down, or have it become disabled and useless until this price is paid.
faction.assets.medicalCenter.description: Salvage and repair damaged assets. Once between turns, if a Special Forces of Military Unit asset on the world is destroyed, the faction may immediately pay half its purchase cost to restore it with one hit point. Any Repair Asset action taken on that world costs one less FacCred for Special Forces and Military Units.
faction.assets.mercenaries.description: Groups of well-equipped, highly-trained soldiers willing to serve the highest bidder. Mercenaries have a maintenance cost of one FacCred per turn. As an action, Mercenaries can move to any world within one hex of their current location. To purchase or move a Mercenary asset to a planet requires government permission.
faction.assets.monopoly.description: An open or tacit straglehold on certain vital businesses or resources on a world. As an action, owners of a monopoly may force one other faction with unstealthed assets on that world to pay them one FacCred. If the target faction can't pay, they lose one asset of their choice on the world.
faction.assets.postechIndustry.descripti: As an action, the owning faction can roll 1d6 for a Postech Industry asset. On a 1, one FacCred is lost, on a 2-4 one FacCred is earned, and a 5-6 returns two FacCreds. If money is lost and no resources are available to pay it, the Postech Industry is destroyed.
faction.assets.pretechManufactories.desc: Rare, precious examples of functioning pretech industrial facilities, retrofitted to work without the benefit of specialized psychic disciplines. As an action, the owning faction can roll 1d8 for a Pretech Manufactory, and gain half that many FacCreds, rounded up.
faction.assets.pretechResearchers.descri: A highly versatile team of research and design specialists capable of supporting limited pretech... as long as they're adequately funded. Any world with Pretech Researchers on it is treated as a tech level 5 for the purpose of buying Cunning and Wealth assets. Pretech researchers have a maintenance cost of 1 FacCred per turn.
faction.assets.randdDepartments.descript: These allow the smooth extension of wealth-creation and industrial principles to the farthest reaches of the faction's operations. A faction with an R&D department may treat all planets as having tech level 4 for purposes of buying Wealth assets.
faction.assets.scavengerFleets.descripti: These rag-tag armadas bring enormous technical and mercantile resources to their patrons, along with a facility with heavy guns. As an action, a Scavenger Fleet can be moved to any world within three hexes. Scavenger Fleets cost 2 FacCreds a turn in maintenance.
faction.assets.shippingCombine.descripti: Transport large amounts of equipment and personnel between worlds. As an action, the combine may move any number of non-Force assets, including itself, to any world within two hexes at a cost of one FacCred per asset.
faction.assets.surveyors.description: Explor potential resource and investment options on worlds. The preence of a surveyor crew allows one additional die to be rolled on Expand Influence actions. As an action, a surveyor crew can be moved to any world within two hexes.
faction.assets.transitWeb.description: These facilities allow almost effortless relocation of all assets. For one FacCred, any number of non-starship Cunning or Wealth assets may be moved between any two worlds within three hexes of the transit web. This may be done freely on the owner's turn so long as the fee can be paid, and using the ability doesn't require an action.
faction.assets.unionToughs.description: These bruisers don't much like scabs and management, and they're willing to take the faction's word on which peaple are which. They're lightly armed and poorly trained, but they can infiltrate to perform sabotage.
faction.assets.ventureCapital.descriptio: This asset grows resources out of seemingly nowhere, harvesting the best of entrepreneurship for the faction's benefit. As an action, venture capital can be tapped. 1d8 is rolled; on a 1, the asset is destroyed, while on a 2-3 one FacCred is gained, 4-7 yields two FacCreds and 8 grants three FacCreds.
faction.assets.gengineeredSlaves.descrip: Only available for factions with the Eugenics Cult tag. Once per turn, the Eugenics Cult can roll an extra d10 on an attack or defense by a Gengineered Slaves asset, regardless of the stat being used. Gengineered Slaves can count as either a Military Unit or Special Forces, determined when the cult first creates a specific asset.
faction.tags.colonists.description: This faction is a fresh colony on a otherwise largely untouched planet. It is this brave band of pioneers that will tame the world's wild forces and bring forth a better life for those who come after.
faction.tags.colonists.effect: This faction has all the benefits of the Planetary Government tag for its homeworld, as no other government exists on a fresh colony. The faction's homeworld is also treated as if it had at leeast tech level 4. Colonies with fewer than 100,000 citizens lack the necessary industrial infrastructure to build Spceship-type assets.
faction.tags.deepRooted.description: This faction has been part of a world's life for time out of mind. Most natives can hardly imagine the world without this faction's presence, and the traditional prerogatives and dignities of the group are instinctively respected.
faction.tags.deepRooted.effect: This faction can roll one additional d10 when defending against attacks on assets on their homeworld. If the faction ever changes homeworlds, this tag is lost.
faction.tags.eugenicsCult.description: The forgidden maltech secrets of advanced human genetic manipulation are known to this faction, and they use them with gusto. Slave-engineered humanoids and "deathless" leadership are just two of the more common alterations these unstable scientists undertake.
faction.tags.eugenicsCult.effect: Eugenics Cultists can buy the Gengineered Slaves asset; it's an asset required Force 1 with the statistics of 6 HP, 2 FacCreds cost, tech level 4 required, with an Attack of Force vs Force/1d6 damage and a Counterattack of 1d4 damage. Once per turn, the Eugenics Cult can roll an extra d10 on an attack or defense by an Gengineered Slaves asset, regardless of the stat being used. Gengineered Slaves can count as either a Military Unit or Special Forces, determined when the cult first creates a specific asset.
faction.tags.exchangeConsulate.descripti: This faction is either led through an Exchange Consulate or has close ties with that pacifistic society of bankers and diplomats. The sophisticated economic services they provide strengthen the faction.
faction.tags.exchangeConsulate.effect: When the faction successfully completes a "Peacable Kingdom" Goal, they may roll 1d6; on a 4+, they gain a bonus experience point. Once per turn, the faction may roll an extra d10 when defending against a Wealth attack.
faction.tags.fanatical.description: The members of this faction just don't know when to quit. No matter how overmatched, the members will keep fighting to the bitter end - and occasionally past it.
faction.tags.fanatical.effect: The faction always rerolls any dice that come up as 1. This zealousness leaves them open at times, however; they always lose ties during attacks.
faction.tags.imperialists.description: This faction nurses wild derams of controlling the sector, whether out of an impulse to bring their local culture and technology to less fortunate worlds or simple lust for dominion. They excel at defeating planetary defenses and standing armies.
faction.tags.imperialists.effect: This faction may roll an extra d10 for attacks made as part of a Seize Planet action.
faction.tags.machiavellian.description: This faction's meat and drink is intrigue, its members delighted in every opportinuty to scheme. It may be a secret cabal of hidden masters or the decadent court of a fallen stellar empire, but its membership has forgotten more of treachtery than most others ever learn.
faction.tags.machiavellian.effect: Once per turn, this faction can roll an additional d10 when making a Cunning attack.
faction.tags.mercenaryGroup.description: The faction sells its services to the highest bidder, and is an extremely mobile organization. Vast amounts of men and material can be moved interstellar distances in just a few months.
faction.tags.mercenaryGroup.effect: All faction assets gain the following special ability: As an action, the asset may move itself to any world within one hex.
faction.tags.perimeterAgency.description: This faction is or is closely tied to an Agency of the enigmatic Perimeter organization. Original organized by the Terran Mandate to detect and contain maltech outbreaks until Mandate fleet resources could be dispatched, the Perimeter retains numerous ancient override codes for pretech security protocols.
faction.tags.perimeterAgency.effect: Once per turn, the faction may roll an additional d10 when making an attack against an asset that requires tech level 5 to purchase. The faction may roll an extra die when making a test to detect Stealthed assets.
faction.tags.pirates.description: This faction is a scourge of the spacelanes, driving up the cost of shipping and terrorizing merchant captains without pity. They steal and refit ships with vicious ingenuity, cobbling together space armadas out of the leavings of their prey.
faction.tags.pirates.effect: Any movement of an asset onto a world that has a Base of Influence for this faction costs one extra FacCred, paid to this faction.
faction.tags.planetaryGovernment.descrip: This faction is the legitimate government of a planet. Rebel groups and rival factions may have assets on the planet, but control over the instruments of the state is firmly in this faction's hands. The faction may rule openly, or it may simply have an inexorable grasp on the existing authorities.
faction.tags.planetaryGovernment.effect: The faction's permissions is required to buy or import those assets marked as needing government permission. This tag can be acquired multiple times, once for each planet the faction controls.
faction.tags.plutocratic.description: This faction prizes wealth, and its membership strives constantly to expand and maintain personal fortunes. Perhaps it is a ruling council of oligarchs or a star-spaning trade cartel.
faction.tags.plutocratic.effect: Once per turn, this faction can roll an additional d10 when making a Wealth attack.
faction.tags.preceptorArchive.descriptio: This faction is or has close ties to a Preceptor Archive a place of learning operated by the learned Preceptors of the Great Archive. These Archives are peaceful institutions dedicated to the spread of practical knowledge and useful engineering to the wider cosmos. Thier large numbers of educated personnel make advanced equipment more practical for deployment.
faction.tags.preceptorArchive.effect: Purchasing an asset that requires tech level 4 or more costs one fewer FacCred than normal. The Preceptor Archive may also take the special action "Teach Planetary Population', costing 2 FacCreds and allowing them to roll 1d12 or one world. On a 12, the world's tech level permanently becomes 3 for the purposes and purchases of this faction.
faction.tags.psychicAcademy.description: Most significant factions are capable of employing pyschics, but this faction can actually train their own. They excel at precise and focused application of the psionic disciplines, and can get far more out of their available psychic resources than other factions.
faction.tags.psychicAcademy.effect: This faction can provide psionic mentor training to qualified psychics. Once per turn, this faction can also force a rival faction to reroll any one d10, whether or not they're involved in the roll.
faction.tags.savage.description: Whether a proud tribe of neoprimates struggling against the material limits of their world or a pack of degenerate tomb world cannibals, this faction is accustomed to surviving without the benefits of advanced technology and maximizing local resources.
faction.tags.savage.effect: Once per turn, this faction can roll an extra die when defending with an asset that requires tech level 0 to purchase.
faction.tags.scavengers.description: This faction might live within the wreckage of a tomb world, salvage the castoffs of some decadent pleasure-world or ply the ruins of an orbital scrapyard. Whatever their territory, this faction knows how to find worth amid seemingly useless trash.
faction.tags.scavengers.effect: Whenever the faction destroys an asset or has one of their assets destroyed, they gain 1 FacCred.
faction.tags.secretive.description: This faction is marked by elaborate protocols of secrecy and misdirection. It may be split up into numerous semi-autonomous cells, or consist largely of trained espionage professionals. Finding assets of such a faction can often be more difficult than destroying them.
faction.tags.secretive.effect: All assets purchased by this faction automatically begin Stealthed. See the list of Cunning assets for details on Stealth.
faction.tags.technicalExpertise.descript: The faction is staffed by large numbers of expert engineers and scientists. They can turn even the most unpromising labor pool into superb technicians.
faction.tags.technicalExpertise.effect: This faction treats all planets on which they have a Base of Influence as if they were at least tech level 4. They can build Starship-type assets on any world with at least ten thousand occupants.
faction.tags.theocratic.description: The faction is fueled by the fierce certainty that God is with them - and with no one else. The tight and occasionally irrational obedience that pervades the organization makes it difficult to infiltrate or subvert effectively.
faction.tags.theocratic.effect: Once per turn, this faction can roll an extra d10 when defnding against a Cunning attack.
faction.tags.warlike.description: There are factions with a military orientation, and then there are factions that just really love killing things. Whether or not this faction has developed sophisticated military resources and techniques, the membership is zealous of battle and has a positive taste for fighting.
faction.tags.warlike.effect: Once per turn, this faction can roll an additional d10 when making a Force attack.
misc.copiedLinkTo: You have copied a link directly to this {entity}.
misc.createASystem: To create a system click and hold a hex to the left.
misc.createEditPlanets: Create and edit planets here from the sidebar.
misc.createRoute.help: Decide what navigation line color, width, and type you would like to create and then select the "Create Route" button. Select any number of hexes to build your route. When you are finished, select "Complete Route" in the sidebar to sync it, or cancel if you would like to start over.
misc.editDeleteRoute.help: In the "Navigation Routes" section, you can select the X to delete any route. There will be a confirmation of deletion. You can hide any route by clicking the checkbox to the right of the route name. To find a given route, you can click on the crosshair icon to highlight it on the map for an interval.
misc.emptyFactionTable: Faction table is empty. Create a faction to begin.
misc.expansionRecommendation: It is recommended that expansion in the horizontal direction should be an even number as it could offset the location of every entity.
misc.factionSaveSector: Begin managing your sector's factions by saving this sector.
misc.featureWithPatreon: Feature your sector here by subscribing with Patreon.
misc.hiddenParrent: A parent entity is hiding this {entity}.
misc.imageExport: The sector image with current layers will be exported to a JPG image.
misc.jsonDescription: Download the entire sector in JSON to import into any custom program.
misc.layerHidden: The {entity} layer is hidden from players
misc.moveSystem: To move an existing system click, hold, and drag.
misc.name: Name
misc.navTips.help.1: Build routes only between two entities at a time. In this way, you can modify these routes individually in the future. In addition, if an entity is hidden and there are routes to that entity, those routes will be hidden automatically from your players.
misc.navTips.help.2: While on the map, you can right click to enter and exit routing mode to save time.
misc.noEntities: You do not have any {entities} in this sector
misc.noExit: Do not exit out of this web page.
misc.oneEntity: One entity per page with a lot of whitespace. Perfect for taking notes.
misc.printEntitiesTable: Print your entities in a table format to easily get an overview of your sector.
misc.receiveEmail: You should be receiving an email soon.
misc.reportProblemPersists: Report a problem if it persists.
misc.routeHiddenByParent: Route is hidden by hidden entity at endpoint
misc.selectedNoChilden: Selected entity has no associated children.
misc.selectEntity: Select an entity on the left to begin
misc.selectHidden: Select to keep hidden from your players.
misc.selectToPaint: Select hexes in sector to paint
misc.syncedAutomatically: Your current sector(s) will be synced automatically
misc.toContinue: Are you sure you want to continue?
misc.toDeleteEntity: Are you sure you want to delete this {entity}?
misc.windowTooSmall: Your browser window is too small to render the sector. Please try on a larger screen.
